ASIA-PAC

China tariffs are to remain until after US election despite the Phase One deal and US officials denied there's a plan to cut China duties further according to people familiar with the matter, while the sources added US is to verify China deal adherence before lifting tariffs and will review, as well possibly trim China tariffs in the future. MARKET RECAP

Earnings season kicked off today with earnings from JP Morgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citi (C). JP Morgan traded ~2% which led to outperformance in the DJ given the banks 3.2% weighting. JPM beat on EPS, revenue, NII and held a strong FICC revenue. Citi (C) also performed well trading with gains just shy of 3% after beats in EPS, Revenue, FICC revenue and investment banking revenue, while WFC noted the EPS includes an impact of litigation accruals of a loss of USD 0.33/shr, although even on an adjusted basis it would still miss analyst expectations. Elsewhere, Amazon (AMZN) reportedly lifted its ban on FedEx (FDX) Ground for third party prime shipments, according to WSJ. Visa (V) acquired Plaid, a fin-tech start up, for USD 5.3bln. WSJ reported previously that in its 2018 funding round it was valued at USD 2.65bln. Apple (AAPL) saw a positive note from Wedbush and UBS with PT upgrades to USD 400 and USD 355, respectively. MGM (MGM) is reportedly near a deal to sell MGM Grand and Mandalay Bay resorts and casinos in Las Vegas to a JV which includes Blackstone (BX), according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter, which could fetch up to USD 4.5bln. SPX -0.15% at 3,283, NDX -0.41% at 9,033, DJI +0.11% at 28,939.

The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Tuesday amid lacklustre US CPI and China trade disappointment. The bids occurred not long after Bunds started trading, and then the T-Note extended the move after the M/M US CPI figures came in a tad weak, with rates falling even further on a risk-off move following reports the US would not be considering further tariff removals for China until after the US election. By settlement, 2s10s was 2bps narrower at 24bps, with the 10-year yield falling more than 3bps, the most pronounced on the curve. US T-note futures (H0) settled 7 ticks higher at 129-04+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 14th January 2020: Risk assets hit after US to limit any further China tariff relief in near future
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 14th January 2020: Risk assets hit after US to limit any further China tariff relief in near future

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities down/flat, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude flat/up

* REAR VIEW: Phase 1 to include USD 200bln purchases from China pledge, but further tariff removal unlikely before US election; CPI doesn’t rock the boat, rising 0.2% M/M; EIA cuts 2020 world oil demand growth by 80k BPD to 1.34mln BPD.

* COMING UP: Data: Swedish CPIF, UK CPI, US NY Fed Manufacturing & PPI, Japanese Machinery Orders. Event: US & China Phase One Signing, OPEC Monthly Report. Speakers: BoE’s Saunders, ECB’s Holzmann, Fed’s Harker & Kaplan. Earnings: GS, BLK, UNH, USB, PNC, BAC. Supply: Germany

 

* US-CHINA: The market saw a relatively acute risk-off move on reports that the US would not be considering further tariff removal until after the US election, removing some investor hopes of further tariff leeway in the near-future, although that is not to say US President Trump could not hint/threat at sooner tariff removal, but such actions are likely to be part of a “Phase 2” agreement, which many expect to not occur until after the US election anyhow. Earlier, Politico reported that the Phase 1 deal (to be signed Wednesday at 11:30 EST / 16:30 GMT) will include a pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period: USD 50bln in energy, USD 40bln in agriculture, USD 35bln-40bln in services and USD 75bln in manufactured goods. The hard figures will serve as a relief to some participants, who have been concerned the deal would contain no hard numbers regarding purchases; however, SCMP reported, citing ex-US trade officials, that doubts remain on whether the full US-China Phase One agreement text will be released, where high-ranking Trump administration officials insist the details will be made available, but there are signs that the full texts and numbers will not be publicly disclosed – USTR Lighthizer has said previously that some parts of the deal, such as China’s commodity purchases, will not be published. The China Global Times Editor later noted that to his knowledge, "China did make a commitment to expand imports from the US", adding "It will be more of a test for the US whether it can provide enough products that Chinese market welcomes.” Meanwhile, as was previously reported, the US Treasury officially removed China from the currency manipulator list in its semi-annual report and said China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in the Phase 1 deal, but also noted that China needs to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. Subsequently, China's Foreign Ministry stated that China will keep their currency basically stable.

* US CPI (DEC): Rose by 0.2% M/M, missing the expected +0.3%, which was also the same pace as the prior, while the core figure rose by 0.1%, also less than the expected +0.2%, which was also the prior pace. However, both the headline and core Y/Y printed 2.3%, as expected, with the headline up from the prior 2.1% and the core unchanged. Pantheon describes the release as “ignorable” and unlikely to mark the start of a sustained shift, noting the core being weighed on by the volatile auto component, airline fares, household operations and lodging costs, whilst the headline was supported more by the firmer energy prices in the month, as was widely expected going into the release. The consultancy concludes that core inflation is stable, but will likely experience some upside bias in H1 this year due to adverse base effects, namely, “medical care, rent, and perhaps modest tariff pass-through in some components where tariffed Chinese imports have large market shares.” With inflation stable and muted, the Fed has little reason to consider a change in interest rates, as market pricing echoes.

* CHINA TRADE DATA (NOV): Chinese November trade metrics are, on the surface at least, strong figures with the overall trade balance (USD-denominated) at 46.79bln vs. prev. 37.93bln, but below the exp. 48.0bln. In terms of exports, this was at 9.0% vs. exp. 2.8% (prev. 1.3%), CapEco note that this data illustrates that the outlook for exports is beginning to improve; albeit, China’s customs noted that trade with the US in 2019 did drop by 10.7% YY – as such, CapEco suggests that the US tariffs remain a drag. In terms of imports, this came in at 16.3% vs. exp. 9.6%; however, the consultancy posits this increase as being almost exclusively attributed to base effects – as such, “it is premature to conclude there has been a marked pick-up in demand.”

* GEOPOLITICS: Libya's Haftar left talks for the ceasefire without signing a deal, which led Turkey to respond by noting if attacks were to continue, they would not be afraid of "teaching them a lesson". Although later reports suggested that Haftar has agreed to further talks, but it is unclear when these will go ahead. In Iraq, there were further reports of an attack on the Taji base, north of Baghdad which sometimes homes US troops, however there were reportedly no casualties.

* FED: Fed’s George (non-voter, hawk) towed the Fed’s line that rates on hold for now is appropriate in her view as the bank assess the economy’s response to the previous rate cuts and the incoming data. George continues to forecast strong consumer spending, continued weakness in manufacturing and business investment this year. On growth, expects GDP growth to slow to its long growth trend of 1.75-2% (Median long-term view stands at 1.9%).

* EIA STEO: Cut its 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 80k BPD to 1.34mln BPD, whilst initiating 2021 world oil demand growth forecast at 1.38mln BPD. 2020 US crude output is to rise 1.06mln BPD to 13.30mln BPD (prev. rise of 913k BPD to 13.18mln BPD), whilst 2021 output is to rise 410k BPD to 13.71mln BPD (initial forecast).

* WTI (G0) SETTLED USD 0.15 HIGHER AT USD 58.23/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 0.29 HIGHER AT USD 64.49/BBL: Energy markets reversed Monday’s losses amid stronger Chinese import data, Libyan geopolitical risk, OPEC+ meeting delays and book squaring ahead of US energy inventory data. The oil benchmarks found support in the earlier European session, alongside an equity rally, finding their peak as US participants came to their desks; WTI (G0) and Brent (H0) printed highs of 58.72 and 65.04, respectively. Elsewhere supporting the bid was reports that Libya’s General Haftar refused to sign an unconditional ceasefire agreement. Furthermore, according to Tass citing sources, OPEC+ is mulling the delay of its March meeting to June, which if so, would see its output cuts extended till then too; the news saw some price strength in the latter part of the session, although the less bullish EIA STEO likely stopped the oil futures setting new highs. However, the late announcement of the US delaying further tariff rollback until after the election helped prices pare back into settlement. Elsewhere, an element of book squaring was likely contributing to price action ahead of the US energy inventories, with the private data report due after the close on Tuesday ahead of the official EIA release on Wednesday. Current inventory expectations (bbls) see crude stocks -0.5mln, distillates +1.2mln, Gasoline +3.4mln.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.15% at 3,283, NDX -0.41% at 9,033, DJI +0.11% at 28,939.

* SECTORS: Materials -0.40%, IT -0.60%, Communication -0.30%, Industrials -0.01%, Financials -0.26%, Staples +0.02%, Utilities +0.27%, Discretionary -0.12%, Energy 0%, Health Care +0.55%.

* EARNINGS: Earnings season kicked off today with earnings from JP Morgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citi (C). JP Morgan traded ~2% which led to outperformance in the DJ given the banks 3.2% weighting. JPM beat on EPS, revenue, NII and held a strong FICC revenue. Its equity markets revenue rose 15% Y/Y to USD .5bln due to higher revenue in prime and cash equities. JPM noted quarterly markets businesses rebounded from a challenging previous year, with resolution of some trade issues supported client activity towards year-end. It also highlighted its quarterly investment banking revenue growth driven by higher debt and equity underwriting fees which was partially offset by lower advisory fees. Citi (C) also performed well trading with gains just shy of 3% after beats in EPS, Revenue, FICC revenue and investment banking revenue. However, its equity market revenue fell 23% to USD 516mln and the bank announced its results included a USD 0.25/shr benefit from tax matters, although even without the benefit it still beat estimates. Wells Fargo (WFC) however capped gains in the financial sector after falling 4%, following a miss on EPS, revenue, NII and NIM, whilst ROE declined from its previous. WFC noted the EPS includes an impact of litgation accruals of a loss of USD 0.33/shr, although even on an adjusted basis it would still miss analyst expectations. Delta Airlines (DAL) traded 4% higher amid its earnings report which beat on top and bottom line estimates and highlighted that it is picking up new customers as its rivals are facing the Boeing (BA) 737 MAX woes; DAL do not fly the 737 MAX. Boston Scientific (BSX) reported preliminary sales which slightly missed estimates, and it also announced FY19 Adj. EPS will be within its previously issued guidance which saw BSX fall over 10%. Gamestop (GME) reported dismal holiday sales, which resulted in a forecast cut for FY19 SSS which sent the stock 10% lower. For all the figures click here: JPM, C, WFC, DAL.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Amazon (AMZN) reportedly lifted its ban on FedEx (FDX) Ground for third party prime shipments, according to WSJ. Visa (V) acquired Plaid, a fin-tech start up, for USD 5.3bln. WSJ reported previously that in its 2018 funding round it was valued at USD 2.65bln. Apple (AAPL) saw a positive note from Wedbush and UBS with PT upgrades to USD 400 and USD 355, respectively. MGM (MGM) is reportedly near a deal to sell MGM Grand and Mandalay Bay resorts and casinos in Las Vegas to a JV which includes Blackstone (BX), according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter, which could fetch up to USD 4.5bln.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H0) SETTLED 7 TICKS HIGHER AT 129-04+. The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Tuesday amid lacklustre US CPI and China trade disappointment. The bids occurred not long after Bunds started trading, and then the T-Note extended the move after the M/M US CPI figures came in a tad weak, with rates falling even further on a risk-off move following reports the US would not be considering further tariff removals for China until after the US election. By settlement, 2s10s was 2bps narrower at 24bps, with the 10-year yield falling more than 3bps, the most pronounced on the curve.

* REPO: The NY Fed announced its month-ahead repo operation schedule where it will continue its overnight operations of at least USD 120bln (unchanged) as well as a series of term repo-operations until Thursday 13th February, whilst maintaining its US T-Bill purchases at a clip of USD 60bln a month. The term operations will be at the 14-day maturity and conducted every Tuesday and Thursday at USD 35bln, until February where it will be cut to USD 30bln, seemingly once the month-end funding pressures subside. Overall, the NY Fed hasn’t made any substantial steps towards a marked reduction in the liquidity it will provide. Some desks had anticipated a cut in both the overnight and term operations, although this has not materialised for the month ahead.

* FX: USD traded within the 97.32-57 parameters with a turnaround from highs post CPI with some slight downside seen after reports US are to keep tariffs on China until after the election. EUR remained above 1.11, likely supported by heavy option expiries on the figure. CHF strengthened against the Euro after the US put Switzerland on its currency manipulator list, with desks noting the move brings the “cat out the bag” in that now attention has been drawn to it, the SNB will be less likely to thwart its strength. GBP retraced some of the post-dovish BoE rhetoric and regained 1.30 to the upside, reportedly breaking through some heavy offers. CAD rather uneventful around the 1.3050 mark. JPY flat against the buck although caught support after reports suggest US is to keep tariffs on China until after the election. CNH lost ground following the reports. XAU remains shy of the 1550 handle, although tested the key figure after the latest US/China update. EMFX was mixed with ZAR and MXN trading flat against the buck, TRY lost further ground amid a breakdown of Libya peace talks. BRL firmer after the government raised its 2020 economic growth and inflation forecasts.

China tariffs are to reportedly remain until after US election despite Phase One deal, US officials deny there's a plan to cut China duties further, according to people familiar with the matter
content:
• "Existing China tariffs will stay until after the election. The U.S. and China have an understanding that no sooner than 10 months after the signing of the deal, the U.S. will verify compliance and potentially trim tariffs now in place on USD 360B." (Click here)
  • Click here for article
reaction_details:
• In an immediate reaction a risk off move was seen across asset classes,
  • E-Mini S&P 500 initially fell 10 points before paring back the majority of the move
  • USDJPY fell from 110.10 to 109.85 before paring back to the 110 figure
  • Spot gold rose from 1544 to 1549 before paring back 1544

 

  • In the aftermath however, the risk off moves across assets continued
analysis_details:
• Comes ahead of the signing of the Phase One deal tomorrow, although specifics of the certain duties are unclear. Although reminder, in the end of 2019 the US and China agreed to a limited deal where the U.S. offered to slash existing tariff rates by half on roughly USD 360 billion in Chinese-made goods, in addition to canceling the December 15th tariffs on USD 156 billion worth of goods.
  • Also, Sept 1, 2019 tariffs (15% on ~USD 125bln worth of imports, would be cut to 7.5% from 15% as part of the Phase One deal.
  • US is still cancelling the December 15th and October 15th tariffs, and September 1st tariffs are still being cut in half to 7.5%. Therefore, that still sees a lot of tariffs in place. Desks note that investors assumed an additional rollback would occur beyond Phase One, although the report states there has been no discussion of any further rollbacks up until the December election.
  • WH Trade Advisor Navarro previously stated that they have the right to implement tariffs if China did not hold up their end of deal
  • NOTE: President Trump previously suggested that it might be best to wait until after the election for Phase Two of the US/China deal, although China had stated that this would be too long of a wait.

Daily FX Wrap: flirting with big figures and ogling outsize option expiries
content:
DXY

The index looks a bit more robust around the 97.500 level, albeit with the Greenback ending Tuesday’s EU session relatively mixed vs major currency counterparts following broadly in line with consensus headline and core CPI data. However, US Treasury yields are softening again and the curve re-flattening amidst an overall stall in risk-on sentiment awaiting Wednesday’s Phase 1 trade deal signing at the White House.

CHF 

The major outlier and outperformer after Switzerland was labelled as an FX manipulator by the US and the Franc rallied on the premise that the SNB may refrain from intervening to keep demand for the safe-haven in check or at least observe a bit more tolerance before stepping in to curb strength. Usd/Chf extended declines through 0.9700 and Eur/Chf tested lows not seen since May 2019 just ahead of light bids said to be sitting at 1.0750 before both pairs based in wake of reactions from the Swiss Government and Central Bank – former claiming no immediate consequences from being included on the list and latter insisting that direct action is completely driven by monetary policy not a desire to gain a competitive edge via devaluation.

GBP/AUD/JPY/EUR/CAD 

All ending narrowly mixed against the Buck, but not before some volatile moves and choppy price action. Cable traded as low as 1.2955 after losing grip of the 1.3000 handle before the Pound recouped almost all its losses and Eur/Gbp pulled back from a test of 0.8600 to just shy of 0.8550. Similarly, the Aussie seemed destined to relinquish 0.6900+ status and lose sight of the round number altogether, but bounced into the NY cut where 1.3 bn expiries between 0.6900-05 ran off, while the Yen encircled 110.00 within a 109.90-110.20 range and Euro gradually drifted towards 1.1100 where even bigger option expiry interest sat (2.5 bn) having briefly breached a key technical level in the form of the 200 DMA (1.1138). Elsewhere, the Loonie has been lethargic nearer the base of a 1.3049-79 band and unable to build on yesterday’s brighter BoC outlook survey elements.

NZD

The Kiwi has been propping up the G10 table for the most part, largely on a loss of momentum from circa 0.6634 overnight highs vs its US peer forged after upbeat Chinese trade data and confirmation that China has been removed from the aforementioned category of deliberate currency depreciators. Nzd/Usd has subsequently skirted 0.6600 and Aud/Nzd climbed to within a whisker of 1.0450 ahead of tonight’s NZ food price index.

SCANDI/EM

Eur/Nok and Eur/Sek have both retreated from early highs on a mixture of chart based selling and a partial recovery in crude prices, but the latter is lagging on the way back down after soft Swedish household consumption prints. Meanwhile, contrasting fortunes for the Try and Cnh as the breakdown of Libya peace talks on Haftar hesitation hampered the Lira, but the Yuan maintained positivity on the trade data and FX news noted above awaiting tomorrow’s Phase One accord signing and hopefully full details of the deal.

US Equity Open Summary: Equities open flat after printing record highs yesterday ahead of tomorrows Phase One signing and as earnings season gets underway
content:
Gainers

  • Perrigo (PRGO) +5% as its CEO highlighted Q3 was strong and Q4 was outstanding whilst providing FY guidance above expectations
  • First Republic Bank (FRC) +4% on top and bottom line beats
  • JP Morgan (JPM) +1.7% after beats across the board (Click here for full release)

Losers

  • Boston Scientific (BSX) -6% following disappointing guidance
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) -3.6% after a poor earnings report. (Click here for full release)
  • Gamestop (GME) -10% on poor holiday sales and a cut in FY SSS guidance
analysis_details:
• Sectors opened with the majority in the red where Healthcare and Energy underperform, with the former weighed on by weakness in Boston Scientific (BSX), who provided disappointing guidance and opened 6% lower. In positive territory, utilities and financials are the only sectors firmer as financials are buoyed by strong earnings from Citi (C) and JP Morgan (JPM) who trade ~2% higher. Gains in the sector are capped however, as Wells Fargo (WFC) disappointed investors on poor earnings. 
  • Following the open slight selling pressure was seen in S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 albeit just off all time highs printed yesterday. Dow Jones remains flat however, as JPM outperforms, which holds a 3.2% weighing in the index.

Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 14th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Earnings from JP Morgan (JPM), Citi (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) 
  • Of note for Pharmaceuticals and Technology names, China Global Times note that as part of the Phase One deal, imports of other products like pharmaceuticals and advanced tech equipment could also expand
  • Visa Inc. (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) is to acquire Plaid, a fin-tech start up, for USD 5.3bln. WSJ reported previously that in its 2018 funding round it was valued at USD 2.65bln.

14th January 2020

Of note for PC names (HPQ, DELL, MSFT), traditional PC volumes in Q4 grew 4.8%, according to IDC preliminary results. Global shipments beat expectations at 71.8mln units, IDC Vice President highlights “The market will still have its challenges ahead, but this year was a clear sign that PC demand is still there despite the continued insurgence of emerging form factors and the demand for mobile computing.”

 

Of note for Pharmaceuticals and Technology names, China Global Times note that as part of the Phase One deal, imports of other products like pharmaceuticals and advanced tech equipment could also expand.

DOW

Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) could reach USD 400/shr in 2020, says Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives, whose channel checks for the iPhone 11 units heading into the March quarter “look robust”, the analyst is also constructive on AirpPods, noting when strong iPhone 11 units are joined with “jaw dropping” momentum from AirPods, Apple should post clear upside in the upcoming quarter with strong guidance for the next quarter. Elsewhere, UBS increased its PT for the name to USD 355 from USD 280 in anticipation of a strong 5G upgrade cycle, highlighting UBS research that 22% of responders indicated that 5G will be a factor when deciding to upgrade. 

Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) is reportedly offering very large discounts, as well as bulk buy deals and maintenance packages to keep orders for the grounded 737 MAX jet, according to the Telegraph, who note the discounts are greater than 50%. Elsewhere, BA could provide Ryanair (RYA LN) its first deliveries of up to ten 737 MAX jets by April, although the timing is dependent upon the regulator, according to RYA LN’s CMO.

JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 2.57 (exp. 2.30), Adj. Revenue 29.21bln (exp. 27.96bln). Net Interest Income (NII) 14.3bln (exp. 14.06bln); NIM 2.38% (exp. 2.365%), FICC sales & Trading revenue 3.45bln (exp. 2.44bln), Investment Bank Revenue 1.82bln (exp. 1.84bln), Equity markets revenue USD 1.5bln, +15% YY due to higher revenue in prime and cash equities, Quarterly ROTCE 17% (prev. 18%). Quarterly markets businesses rebounded from a challenging previous year; resolution of some trade issues supported client activity towards year-end. Quarterly investment banking revenue growth driven by higher debt and equity underwriting fees which was partially offset by lower advisory fees. Guides Q1 2020 incremental NII ~USD 14bln (exp. 13.95bln), guides Q1 2020 adj. expense ~17.0bln (exp. 16.7bln).

McDonald's Corp. (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) is reportedly testing chicken sandwiches with monosodium glutamate which adds taste, although has come under scrutiny regarding health concerns from consumers. 

Visa Inc. (V) (Information Technology/IT Services) is to acquire Plaid, a fin-tech start up, for USD 5.3bln. WSJ reported previously that in its 2018 funding round it was valued at USD 2.65bln.

NASDAQ 100

Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) will reportedly ask a judge to temporarily block Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) from working on the USD 10bln JEDI cloud contract, according to a court filing.

Amgen Inc. (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) and Qiagen (QGEN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) announced a strategic collaboration for AMG 510, an investigational cancer treatment. 

Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) had its PT increased to USD 600 from USD 500 by Jefferies, who maintain a Buy rating on the shares noting it would be wrong to exit the automaker on valuation. 

T-Mobile (TMUS) and Sprint (S) (Communication Services/ Wireless Telecommunication Services) have asked a federal judge that their case to merge is provided with proper weight, stating the district AG’s who were suing over the merger did not consider the plans both companies had to preserve competition within the sector.

S&P 500

Boston Scientific (BSX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) gave preliminary Q4 adj. EPS 0.42-0.45 (exp. 0.44), Q4 preliminary sales 2.9bln (exp. 2.93bln); believes it will exceed Q4 EPS guidance of 0.22-0.25/shr and FY19 EPS of 0.72-0.75. Estimates FY19 adj. EPS will be within USD 1.55-1.58, as per previously issued guidance.

Citigroup Inc (C) (Financials/Diversified Banks) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 2.15 (tax adj. ~1.90) (exp. 1.87), Revenue 18.38bln (exp. 17.89bln), FICC revenue 2.90bln (exp. 2.37bln), investment banking revenue 1.35bln (exp. 1.26bln), equity market revenue 516mln (-23%). Q4 results including circa a USD 0.25/shr benefit from tax matters.

Delta Air Lines Inc (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) Q4 19 (USD): Adj. EPS 1.70 (exp. 1.38), Revenue 11.44bln (exp. 11.35bln). Q1 adj. TRASM view flat to +2%; total revenue growth view at 5-7%. Co says it is picking up new customers as rivals face Boeing (BA) 737 MAX woes (Note, DAL does not fly 737 MAX jets).

First Republic Bank (FRC) (Financials/Regional Banks) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 1.39 (exp. 1.27), Revenue 0.878 (exp. 0.86bln).

Hess Corporation (HES) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) – Elliott Associates exited its position in the company.

IHS Markit Ltd. (INFO) (Industrials/Research & Consulting Services) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.65 (exp. 0.60), Revenue 1.12bln (exp. 1.12bln). Backs FY20 Adj. EPS forecast of 2.82 to 2.88 (exp. 2.86) and revenue of 4.52-4.59bln (exp. 4.58bln). Sees FY20 Adj. EBITDA between 1.86-1.89bln.

Lilly (Eli) & Co. (LLY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it added two more options for those who use its insulin, which will have 50% lower list prices than the original. LLY noted that 10% of those using the original Humalog insulin injector transferred to the cheaper option.

McKesson Corp. (MCK) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) raises FY20 EPS view to between (USD) 14.60-14.80 (exp. 14.41, prev. 14.00-14.60)

MGM Resorts International (MGM) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming) is nearing a deal to sell MGM Grand and Mandalay Bay resorts and casinos in Las Vegas to a JV which includes Blackstone (BX), according to WSJ citing people familiar with the matter; Financial terms not disclosed but it could value MGM Grand a USD 2.5bln.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) had its PT upgraded to USD 310 from USD 275 at Oppenheimer, highlighting the management team and their ability to perform well in a challenging environment.

Cloudera (CLDR) (Information Technology/Software) has named its new CEO as Robert Bearden, an experienced enterprise software executive who was CEO of Hortwon works, which merged with CLDR last year.

Gamestop (GME) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) total global holiday sales -27.5% at USD 1.83bln and thus cut its FY19 comparable sales forecast to down 19-21% (prev. decline in high teens) and expects an adjusted net loss for the fiscal year.

Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Road & Rail) is putting together a number of council experts to help advise it on safety initiatives for both customers and drivers.

STAG Industrial (STAG) (Real Estate/Equity Real Estate Investment Trust’s) 8.75mln spot secondary share offering (prev. 8mln) was priced at USD 31.40, within the USD 31.35-31.70 target range.

TreeHouse (THS) and Post Holdings (POST) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) announced the termination of its agreement to sell it’s ready to eat cereal business to POST after coming to a mutual agreement; THS announced it will continue to look for a buyer for the unit.

Wipro Ltd (WIT) (Information Technology/IT Services) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.06 (exp. 0.06), Revenue 2.2bln (exp. 2.2bln).

subject: China Global Times Editor notes that to his knowledge, "China did make a commitment to expand imports from the US", adding "It will be more of a test for the US whether it can provide enough products that Chinese market welcomes"
content: • Link to tweet
analysis_details:
• Sources earlier confirmed that the US-China Phase One deal will include a pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period. This is said to include USD 50bln in energy, USD 40bln in agriculture, USD 35bln-40bln in services and USD 75bln in manufactured goods. SCMP note that questions remain as to whether China can achieve the USD 40bln in agricultural purchases that the Trump administration is touting. China is yet to official confirm the buys.
  • White House Trade Adviser Navarro asserted that the Phase One deal will allow the US to swiftly reimpose tariffs if it unilaterally determines that China has broken any of its commitments, including purchase agreements. China Global Times opinion tweeted that China will surely follow up its commitment to increase imports from the US once barriers such as tariffs and other administrative measures are lifted.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt and Dollar take US data largely in stride
content: Only knee-jerk and minimal moves in wake of CPI as less volatile y/y inflation rates were bang in line with consensus and quickly overshadowed the slightly softer m/m prints. Hence, bonds are back up near best levels or marginal new highs, with Bunds nudging 171.00 vs 171.08, Gilts at 132.30 vs 132.47 at one stage and 10 year USTs hovering above 129-00 from 129-02. Meanwhile, the DXY has reclaimed 97.500+ status from 97.574 pre-data, as Eur/Usd continues to slip towards 1.1100 and a particularly large option expiry.

subject: PRIMER: Fed’s Williams (Voter, Neutral) moderating a panel on 'Behavioral Science and Organisational Culture' at 14:00GMT/09:00EST
content:
Recent commentary

  • On the economy, Williams noted the housing market is picking up from a year ago and consumer spending is strong, expects US economy to grow by about 2% over the next couple of years, says low and stable inflation isn't a concern, but wants to avoid falling inflation. He expects to see growth around 2.25%, unemployment around 3.5% and inflation remaining soft, haven’t seen inflationary pressures emerge, reiterates data dependence.
  • On policy, Williams noted monetary policy is accomodative and is supporting growth. Material change in economic outlook will cause him to change outlook. Williams says there are still significant risks to the downside, citing trade and geopolitical uncertainty. He believes monetary policy is in the right place.
  • On the repo-operations, says they have been very effective and money markets are moving smoothly.

Also of note

  • Fed median dots (2020): GDP +2%, Unemployment 3.5%, PCE +1.9%, Core PCE +1.9%, FFR 1.6% (no rate moves). NOTE: Atlanta Fed currently tracking GDP at 2.3% in Q4 19.
  • Today's other Fed speak emainates from George (Non-Voter) at 18:00GMT/13:00EST

subject: PREVIEW: US CPI (December 2019)
content:
• The Street expects CPI to rise +0.2% M/M (prev. +0.3%), and 2.3% Y/Y (from 2.1%); the core metric is seen rising 0.2% M/M, matching the prior pace, while the Y/Y rate is seen unchanged at 2.3%. UBS thinks upside will be driven in the food and energy components, given that gasoline prices rose by 2.75% in December. The ‘other goods’ category may also continue to see upside, as the impact of the September tariffs continues to feed through, but UBS notes that, up until now, the impact has been modest. Lloyd’s are also in view of the general consensus, however the desk highlights inflation is not a particular concern at the Fed right now, where instead policy makers are focusing on how the economy fared in Q4; eyes on retail sales Thursday, industrial production, preliminary University of Michigan survey and housing data on Friday.
  • Looking ahead, UBS sees the Y/Y CPI rate rising to 2.5% in the January data, before slowing again; and similarly, sees the Fed’s preferred measure of inflation, core PCE, rising to the 2.0% target in the spring, before easing. NOTE: Many policy makers have expressed that for any chance of a rate hike, inflation would have to drastically rise past the banks 2% target, although currently standing this is unlikely for some time with the Fed currently on hold; current market pricing sees no rate changes throughout the year and beyond.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 14th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are relatively unchanged in choppy trade on quiet newsflow in European hours
  • US Treasury removed China from the currency manipulator list, said China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in the Phase 1 deal
  • US-China Phase 1 deal will include pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period
  • Chinese trade date showed a sizable increase in the trade balance, albeit this did miss (USD-denominated) expectations
  • USD is firmer but the DXY is still below 97.50, while the debt complex is tentative ahead of Phase 1 signing
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NFIB Business Optimism, CPI, EIA STEO, APIs, US Democratic Debate, Fed’s Williams & George
  • Earnings: JP Morgan, Wells Fargo, Citi and Delta Airlines

ASIA-PAC: US-China Analysis Piece available on the headline feed

Asian equity markets were somewhat mixed as the region took its cue from the fresh record levels on Wall St amid the backdrop of the trade optimism heading into this week’s Phase 1 deal signing and after the US removed its designation of China as a currency manipulator. ASX 200 (+0.9%) followed suit to its US peers and posted a fresh all-time high led by tech and defensives, as well as the broad sectoral gains aside from gold miners which lagged due to losses in the precious metal, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) tested the 24k milestone on return from an extended weekend and with early advances spurred by a predominantly favourable currency. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) also initially benefitted from the trade developments in which the US backtracked just 5 months after it had labelled China a currency manipulator and with the initial details of the Phase 1 deal said to confirm China’s pledge to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period, while the latest Chinese trade data added to the encouragement as Trade Balance, Exports and Imports mostly surpassed estimates for December although Chinese markets eventually gave back their gains and the data had also showed trade with the US contracted by 10.7% Y/Y throughout 2019. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and slipped below the 152.00 with demand dampened by the gains across stocks and with a relatively tepid BoJ Rinban announcement for just JPY 130bln of JGBs doing little to underpin prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.8954 vs. Exp. 6.8957 (Prev. 6.9263)

US Treasury removed China from the currency manipulator list in its semi-annual report and said China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in the Phase 1 deal but also noted that China needs to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. Furthermore, the report added that no major US trading partner met the criteria to be designated a currency manipulator and that it is continuing to monitor China, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam and Switzerland currency practices, while Taiwan and Thailand are nearing the threshold to be added into the monitoring list. (Newswires)

Subsequently, China's Foreign Ministry states that China will keep their currency basically stable. (Newswires)

US-China Phase 1 deal will include pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period including USD 50bln in energy, USD 40bln in agriculture, USD 35bln-40bln in services and USD 75bln in manufactured goods. (Politico)

USTR Lighthizer said they have about finished translation of the Phase 1 deal which includes commitment regarding currency manipulation, while White House Trade Adviser Navarro commented that the Phase 1 deal will allow the US to swiftly reimpose tariffs if it unilaterally determines that China has broken any of its commitments. In related news, Chinese officials will meet with American companies to send the message that China is open for business, according to FBN's Lawrence citing sources. (Newswires/Twitter)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Nov) 330B vs. Exp. 315.0B (Prev. 274.2B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (CNY)(Nov) Y/Y 9.0% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 1.3%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(Nov) Y/Y 17.7% vs. Exp. 8.8% (Prev. 2.5%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 46.79B vs. Exp. 48.0B (Prev. 37.93B) Chinese Exports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 7.6% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. -1.3%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 16.3% vs. Exp. 9.6% (Prev. 0.5%)

China Customs noted that 2019 trade with US fell 10.7% Y/Y. There were also comments by Customs Vice Minister Zhou that the Phase 1 deal will boost Chinese imports from US but won't affect China's imports from other countries, while Zhou added that trade growth still faces complex external environment this year. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump’s administration plans to reallocate USD 7.2bln of defence funds for the border wall. (Newswires)

US Senator Cornyn commented that the Senate could conduct a vote on USMCA this week. (Newswires)

The Trump Administration has taken steps to spare investors from Australia, Canada and the UK from some of its restrictions on foreign investments, due to take effect on February 13th. (FT) Yesterday, the Trump Administrations issues a set of rules that will look to intensify scrutiny of foreign investments in US companies.

GEOPOLITICS

Twitter reports stated that Libya’s GNA signed the ceasefire but LNA’s General Haftar left Moscow without signing the ceasefire according to sources, while reports also noted heavy gunfire in Salah al-Din and Ain Zara areas of Libya's capital Tripoli. (Twitter)

Turkish President Erdogan says Turkey will not refrain from teaching Haftar a lesson if attacks continue against Libya. (Newswires)

France, Britain and German are to instigate the Iranian Nuclear Deal dispute mechanism on Tuesday., according to diplomats. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Economists warned that next BoE Governor Bailey and UK Chancellor Javid have to take early measures to ensure the BoE has tools to deploy for the next recession. (FT) Note, this was the findings of a survey conducted in December.

Senior US Officials told Ministers in the UK that utilising Huawei’s technology in the UK’s 5G network would place trans-Atlantic intelligence sharing at risk. (Guardian)

ECB's Mersch (Hawkish) states that the economy appears to be stabilising, as does inflation. (Newswires)

EQUITIES – JPM, WFC & C preview available on the Headline feed, surmised below

Brief Earnings Preview:

-        JPM: Q4 EPS is expected to print at USD 2.30 (Prev. USD 1.98 YY), whilst Revenues are seen coming in at USD 27.96bln (Prev. USD 26.8bln YY).

o    Some desks note that the all the above forecasts seem light based on trading guidance announced at the Goldman Sachs conference.

o    In terms of recent history, JPM have topped estimates for three straight quarters.

-        WFC: Q4 EPS expected at USD 1.10 (Prev. USD 1.09 YY), with Revenues at USD 20.1bln (Prev. USD 20.98bln YY). NII is forecast at USD 11.22bln and NIM at 2.54%.

o    In terms of recent history, WFC posted mixed earnings with two out of the last three quarters missing street estimates.

-        C: Q4 EPS expected at USD 1.87 and Revenues at USD 17.89bln. NII is seen printing at USD 11.76bln with NIM at 2.58%

o    Analysts forecast total trading revenues in the high teens and IB revenues unchanged.

A choppy session thus far for European equities [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%], in what started off on more of a downbeat note for the region, following on from a mixed APAC trade. Equity markets remain on standby ahead of US earnings season, which is set to kick off today, and with traders also eyeing tomorrow’s US-China Phase One deal signing. Sectors are largely in the green with no clear reflection of the overall risk sentiment. Individual movers have garnered more attention – with reports of credit card gambling to be banned in April this year weighing down on the likes of William Hill (-1.2%) and GVC (-0.8%), albeit the shares are off lows seen at the open. Meanwhile, Dialog Semiconductor (-1.4%) fell post-earnings after reporting a deterioration in EPS. Renault (-0.2%) failed to gain much traction after yesterday’s reports of a supposed end to the Nissan-Renault alliance were dismissed. Evonik (-4.2%) fell and remains at the foot of the Stoxx 600 after noting that revenue will be slightly below the prior YY and after RAG-Stiftung proposed the sale of around 24mln shares in the Co. On the flip side, miners are benefitting from yesterday’s surge in copper prices with Antofagasta (+1.7%), Glencore (+0.6%) also experiencing tailwinds from broker upgrades. Head-up, US earnings season will unofficially commence with earnings from JP Morgan, who accounts for around 3.2% of the DJIA, Wells Fargo and Citi.

FX

USD - The Dollar is holding a modestly firm line, with the DXY just shy of the 97.500 level ahead of US inflation data that is forecast to accelerate in headline terms and remain steady at the core. However, the Greenback’s stability between 97.455-339 owes much to weakness elsewhere as only the Swiss Franc is stronger amongst major currency peers, with Usd/Chf back below 0.9700 and Eur/Chf sub-1.0800.

GBP/CAD/AUD/NZD/JPY/EUR - The Pound is still succumbing to downside pressure on downbeat UK data and dovish BoE policy implications, as Cable extends declines through 1.3000 to circa 1.2955 and Eur/Gbp breaches December peaks before running into resistance ahead of 0.8600 and highs from November just pips above the round number. Elsewhere, the Loonie has lost mild traction gleaned from Monday’s relatively encouraging Q4 BoC business survey findings, with Usd/Cad back above 1.3050, while the Aussie and Kiwi have also handed back some gains made on the back of strong Chinese trade data overnight and confirmation that China has made enough FX pledges within the Phase 1 trade accord for the US to retract it from the currency manipulation list. Aud/Usd is under 0.6900 again, but may derive underlying support given hefty option expiry interest at 0.6900-05 (1.3 bn) and Nzd/Usd is losing altitude between 0.6634-17 parameters ahead of December’s NZ food price index. Conversely, the Yen is trying to pare losses within a 109.90-110.20 range amidst a degree of consolidation in broad risk sentiment, and the Euro is firm on the 1.1100 handle, albeit failing to sustain gains beyond 1.1145 after eclipsing the 200 DMA and flanked by more big expiries (2.2 bn between 1.1160-70 and 2.5 bn at the 1.1100 strike).

SCANDI - The Crowns are narrowly mixed with Eur/Sek elevated in a circa 10.5590-10.5285 band vs Eur/Nok straddling 9.9000 after weaker than forecast Swedish household consumption metrics and with the latter keeping tabs with oil prices.

EM - A decent pick-up in Turkish IP has not really helped the Lira to escape more geopolitical jitters as efforts to broker peace in Libya have been scuppered by the Hafta group leaving talks in Russia without signing on the dotted line. Usd/Try is hovering just below 5.9000 and extending its rebound in contrast to Usd/Cnh that continues to probe lower after breaching 6.9000 on the aforementioned US-China trade and FX positivity. Note also, Nomura notes that CTAs have flipped positions to net Yuan long vs the Buck for the first time since the start of Q2 last year, while covering shorts in the non-US Dollar commodity bloc

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1100 (2.5BLN), 1.1140-50 (750M), 1.1160-70 (2.2BLN), 1.1190-1.1200 (1.2BLN)

-        AUD/USD: 0.6870 (278M), 0.6890 (250M), 0.6900-05 (1.3BLN), 0.6930-35 (760M)

FIXED INCOME

Core bonds remain bid, but off best levels as stocks and risk sentiment in general settle down after several wobbles since the start of EU trade. Bunds are back below 171.00 after poking their head above the parapet, albeit still comfortably above the 170.65 Eurex base and more on an even keel with Gilts at 132.23 within 132.47-10 Liffe extremes that may be seeing some post-DMO auction hedge unwinding following decent, though not especially strong results. However, Spanish Bonds are hugging intraday highs amidst stonking demand for the new 2030 syndication and US Treasuries are closer to overnight session peaks than troughs ahead of CPI data and a couple of Fed speakers.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures are ultimately on a firmer footing after erasing overnight losses - with the former rebounding off its 200 DMA (USD 57.74/bbl) whilst the latter found a base around the psychological USD 64/bbl mark. News flow has been light for the session thus far, although eyes remain on macro developments such as Middle Eastern tensions and US-China trade. Desks note that expectations for a well-supplied market are not currently reflected in the time spreads, with ICE Brent spreads still in deep backwardation, suggesting the physical market remains tight. On a more micro-level, traders will be looking for the EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook and API releases later today, with ING noting that participants would be eyeing the former for its forecast of US production growth; “with the falling rig count, the positive supply growth estimates for the US are increasingly coming under question”, the Dutch bank says. Wednesday will see the release of the OPEC monthly report, followed by the IEA’s report on Thursday to round up this month’s oil market releases. Elsewhere, spot gold remains tentative just below USD 1550/oz amid a lack of fresh fundamental catalysts, albeit the yellow metal printed a fresh YTD low ~USD 1536/oz overnight. Copper meanwhile holds onto a lion’s share of yesterday’s gains after prices briefly topped USD 2.85/lb – with traders citing an overall more positive macro sentiment, with the Phase One deal signing inching closer. Finally, industry sources note that Chinese demand for high-grade iron is poised to drop as steel mills attempt to cut costs and raise profit margins.

However, Spanish Bonds are hugging intraday highs amidst stonking demand for the new 2030 syndication and US Treasuries are closer to overnight session peaks than troughs ahead of CPI data and a couple of Fed speakers.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month future are ultimately on a firmer footing after erasing overnight losses - with the former rebounding off its 200 DMA (USD 57.74/bbl) whilst the latter found a base around the psychological USD 64/bbl mark. News flow has been light for the session thus far, although eyes remain on macro developments such as Middle Eastern tensions and US-China trade. Desks note that expectations for a well-supplied market are not currently reflected in the time spreads, with ICE Brent spreads still in deep backwardation, suggesting the physical market remains tight. On a more micro-level, traders will be looking for the EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook and API releases later today, with ING noting that participants would be eyeing the former for its forecast of US production growth; “with the falling rig count, the positive supply growth estimates for the US are increasingly coming under question”, the Dutch bank says. Wednesday will see the release of the OPEC monthly report, followed by the IEA’s report on Thursday to round up this month’s oil market releases. Elsewhere, spot gold remains tentative just below USD 1550/oz amid a lack of fresh fundamental catalysts, albeit the yellow metal printed a fresh YTD low ~USD 1536/oz overnight. Copper meanwhile holds onto a lion’s share of yesterday’s gains after prices briefly topped USD 2.85/lb – with traders citing an overall more positive macro sentiment, with the Phase One deal signing inching closer. Finally, industry sources note that Chinese demand for high-grade iron is poised to drop as steel mills attempt to cut costs and raise profit margins.

subject: US EARNINGS PREVIEWS – JP MORGAN (JPM), CITI (C), WELLS FARGO (WFC)
content:
*OVERVIEW: Earnings season is set to unofficially kick off today with results from three major banks set to report before the opening bell (see below).

According to Zack’s, S&P 500 earnings are expected to be down 3.7% in Q4 Y/Y, though revenues are seen rising 3.4% Y/Y. The aggregate numbers are likely to be dragged down by the energy sector, where earnings are forecast to decline by around 42% Y/Y, and revenues are seen slipping 4.6% Y/Y.

The finance names reporting this week (JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Citigroup on Tuesday; Goldman Sachs, BlackRock on Wednesday) will set the tone, given that earnings growth in the finance sector are seen rising 7.5%, with revenue growth of 6.3%). The analysts suggested that earnings have been flat over the last three quarters, which is likely to continue; that said, major banks are seen reporting earnings decline of 9.8%, following the -0.6% in the previous quarter. 

*JP MORGAN (3.2% DJIA weighting) – 06:55EST/11:55GMT

  • Q4 EPS is expected to print at USD 2.30 (Prev. USD 1.98 YY), whilst Revenues are seen coming in at USD 27.96bln (Prev. USD 26.8bln YY). Analysts also expect Net Interest Income (NII) at USD 14.06bln and Net Interest Margin (NIM) at 2.35%. Further, provision forecasts stand at USD 1.52bln, NCO at USD 1.46bln and non-interest income at USD 13.2bln. Some desks note that the all the above forecasts seem light based on trading guidance announced at the Goldman Sachs conference. The Street also sees trading revenue up in the high teens and Investment Bank (IB) revenue relatively unchanged. In terms of recent history, JPM have topped estimates for three straight quarters.
  • The current analysts rating on the shares is “hold”; with 2 “strong buy”, 6 “buy”, 16 “holds” and 3 “sells”, according to newswires

*WELLS FARGO – 08:00EST/1300GMT

  • Analysts see Q4 EPS at USD 1.10 (Prev. USD 1.09 YY), with Revenues at USD 20.1bln (Prev. USD 20.98bln YY). NII is forecast at USD 11.22bln and NIM at 2.54%. Provisions and NCOs are expected to print at USD 771mln and USD 744mln respectively and non-interest income at USD 8.806bln. Mortgage banking income is forecast to come in at around USD 775mln. In terms of recent history, WFC posted mixed earnings with two out of the last three quarters missing street estimates.
  • The current analysts rating on the shares is “hold”; with 1 “strong buy”, 3 “buy”, 16 “holds”, 5 “sell” and 3 “strong sell”, according to newswires

*CITI - 08:00EST/ 1300GMT

  • The Street expects Q4 EPS at USD 1.87 and Revenues at USD 17.89bln. NII is seen printing at USD 11.76bln with NIM at 2.58%. Provisions are forecast at USD 2.12bln, NCO at USD 2.02vlb and non-interest income at USD 6.33bln. Further, analysts forecast total trading revenues in the high teens and IB revenues unchanged.
  • The current analysts rating on the shares is “buy”; with 6 “strong buy”, 17 “buy”, 3 “hold” and 1 “sell”, according to newswires

subject: FX Morning Colour: Franc firm, Sterling soft and Buck buoyed pre-US CPI
content:
USD

The Dollar is holding a modestly firm line, with the DXY just shy of the 97.500 level ahead of US inflation data that is forecast to accelerate in headline terms and remain steady at the core. However, the Greenback’s stability between 97.455-339 owes much to weakness elsewhere as only the Swiss Franc is stronger amongst major currency peers, with Usd/Chf back below 0.9700 and Eur/Chf sub-1.0800.

GBP/CAD/AUD/NZD/JPY/EUR

The Pound is still succumbing to downside pressure on downbeat UK data and dovish BoE policy implications, as Cable extends declines through 1.3000 to circa 1.2955 and Eur/Gbp breaches December peaks before running into resistance ahead of 0.8600 and highs from November just pips above the round number. Elsewhere, the Loonie has lost mild traction gleaned from Monday’s relatively encouraging Q4 BoC business survey findings, with Usd/Cad back above 1.3050, while the Aussie and Kiwi have also handed back some gains made on the back of strong Chinese trade data overnight and confirmation that China has made enough FX pledges within the Phase 1 trade accord for the US to retract it from the currency manipulation list. Aud/Usd is under 0.6900 again, but may derive underlying support given hefty option expiry interest at 0.6900-05 (1.3 bn) and Nzd/Usd is losing altitude between 0.6634-17 parameters ahead of December’s NZ food price index. Conversely, the Yen is trying to pare losses within a 109.90-110.20 range amidst a degree of consolidation in broad risk sentiment, and the Euro is firm on the 1.1100 handle, albeit failing to sustain gains beyond 1.1145 after eclipsing the 200 DMA and flanked by more big expiries (2.2 bn between 1.1160-70 and 2.5 bn at the 1.1100 strike).

SCANDI

The Crowns are narrowly mixed with Eur/Sek elevated in a circa 10.5590-10.5285 band vs Eur/Nok straddling 9.9000 after weaker than forecast Swedish household consumption metrics and with the latter keeping tabs with oil prices.

EM 

A decent pick-up in Turkish IP has not really helped the Lira to escape more geopolitical jitters as efforts to broker peace in Libya have been scuppered by the Hafta group leaving talks in Russia without signing on the dotted line. Usd/Try is hovering just below 5.9000 and extending its rebound in contrast to Usd/Cnh that continues to probe lower after breaching 6.9000 on the aforementioned US-China trade and FX positivity. Note also, Nomura notes that CTAs have flipped positions to net Yuan long vs the Buck for the first time since the start of Q2 last year, while covering shorts in the non-US Dollar commodity bloc.

subject: Nomura Quants: Speculators continue to eagerly purchase US stocks
content:
• The tone in global stock markets has been supported by recent trade optimism, however, Nomura also cites the possibility that some speculative players may have resigned themselves to “joining the herd in chasing the market up” (notes the lack of convincing dips to buy).
  • Long/short funds appear to have a particularly bullish stance on the IT sector with a tilt towards shorting financials and industrials with the aim of targeting any potential short-term reversal in the market.
  • CTAs are estimated to have been relentless purchasing S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 futures without self-imposing checks on the extent of their long positions.
  • 3250 in the S&P is estimated to signal the average break-even line for net buying since the beginning of December with the level climbing over the timeframe. Given the S&P closed at 3288 yesterday, there is potential for the market to chase up gains even more.
  • In the FX space, Nomura estimates that CTAs have switched to a net short position in USD/CNH for the first time since April 2019. Alongside purchasing CNH, CTAs have covered the entirety of their net shorts in major commodity currencies; AUD, CAD and NZD.

subject: ANALYSIS: Phase One signing imminent; focus shifts to Phase Two
content:
*PHASE ONE OVERVIEW

China’s Vice Premier Liu He has arrived in Washington for the much-anticipated signing of the US-China Phase One trade deal, with reports via WSJ suggesting that it will take place at the White House on January 15th at 11:30EST/16:30GMT/00:30HKT.

*THE NITTY-GRITTY

*China’s Currency Manipulation Status: US Treasury removed China from the currency manipulator list in its semi-annual report and said China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in the Phase One deal, but also noted that China needs to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. Sources familiar with the negotiations noted that the currency manipulator designation previously had no real consequences for China, albeit its removal was a symbol of goodwill from the US for Chinese officials. As a result of the overall optimism, CNY strengthened further below 6.9000 vs. the USD to levels last seen in July last year.

*China’s Agreed Purchases: Sources confirmed that the US-China Phase One deal will include a pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period. This is said to include USD 50bln in energy, USD 40bln in agriculture, USD 35bln-40bln in services and USD 75bln in manufactured goods. SCMP note that questions remain as to whether China can achieve the USD 40bln in agricultural purchases that the Trump administration is touting. China is yet to official confirm the buys.

* Sticking Points: The Phase One deal does include various advances on some sticking points. China Global Times noted that the deal text includes nine chapters, including IPR, technology transfer, food and agriculture, financial services, exchange rate and transparency, expanding trade, bilateral evaluation, dispute settlement and final agreement. US business executives suggested the Phase One deal is ‘modest but helpful’. That said, China has been tempering optimism surrounding the overall trade war with the US, stating that “it is not over yet” via its social media proxy Taoran, which is affiliated with the Communist paper used to manage trade talk expectations. “The US hasn’t revoked all its tariffs on China and China is still implementing retaliatory measures. There are still many uncertainties down the road” - Toaran noted, cited by SCMP.

*Enforcement: White House Trade Adviser Navarro asserted that the Phase One deal will allow the US to swiftly reimpose tariffs if it unilaterally determines that China has broken any of its commitments, including purchase agreements. China Global Times opinion tweeted that China will surely follow up its commitment to increase imports from the US once barriers such as tariffs and other administrative measures are lifted.

*Semi-Annual Review: The two nations have also agreed on semi-annual dialogue to push reforms in US and China and resolve disputes. This agreement is also poised to be announced on January 15th alongside the signing of the of the Phase One trade deal, according to WSJ. The new talks dubbed “Comprehensive Economic Dialogue”, will be separate from the Phase Two negotiations.

*PHASE TWO FOCUS

With the Phase One signing almost certainly taking place, market focus now shifts onto Phase Two, which is said to contain a lion’s share of the remaining sticking points. Some desks note that the Phase One deal signing seems to be more theatre than meaningful change – noting that the semi-annual review as a simple return to conditions seen in 2016, whilst the dropped currency manipulation status is likely a move to acquire leverage against China alongside the majority of tariffs being kept in place.

*Format: The actual format and timing of the Phase Two deal is not yet known. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin alluded late last year that Phase Two negotiations will begin after Phase One is out of the way, but may be compartmentalised – “Phase Two may be 2a, 2b, 2c, we’ll see, but this is unto itself a huge accomplishment for the president”, Mnuchin noted.

*Timing: US President Trump last week he might want to wait till after the election to complete Phase Two China trade deal, but also said the US will begin Phase Two talks straight away. China Global Times, in response, tweeted that a Phase Two trade deal after November is too far away and added that China's willingness to start Phase Two negotiations depends on the implementation of the Phase One deal; citing an expert close to the Chinese Government. Furthermore, Global Times citing the expert close to the Chinese government, stated that China is not in a rush to begin Phase Two talks if US President Trump criticises the country during his election campaign.

*BRIEF HISTORY OF US-SINO DEVELOPMENTS – Link

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

14th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took its cue from the fresh record levels on Wall St amid the backdrop of the trade optimism heading into this week’s Phase 1 deal signing and after the US removed its designation of China as a currency manipulator. ASX 200 (+0.9%) followed suit to its US peers and posted a fresh all-time high led by tech and defensives, as well as the broad sectoral gains aside from gold miners which lagged due to losses in the precious metal, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) tested the 24k milestone on return from an extended weekend and with early advances spurred by a predominantly favourable currency. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) also initially benefitted from the trade developments in which the US backtracked just 5 months after it had labelled China a currency manipulator and with the initial details of the Phase 1 deal said to confirm China’s pledge to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period, while the latest Chinese trade data added to the encouragement as Trade Balance, Exports and Imports mostly surpassed estimates for December although Chinese markets eventually gave back their gains and the data had also showed trade with the US contracted by 10.7% Y/Y throughout 2019.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 14th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took its cue from the fresh record levels on Wall St amid the backdrop of trade optimism
  • US Treasury removed China from the currency manipulator list in its semi-annual report
  • US-China Phase 1 deal will include a pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period including USD 40bln in agriculture
  • Chinese trade balance, exports and imports mostly surpassed estimates for December; trade with the US contracted by 10.7% Y/Y throughout 2019
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US NFIB Business Optimism, CPI, EIA STEO, APIs, US Democratic Debate, ECB’s Mersch, Fed’s Williams, George, supply from Italy and the UK
  • Earnings: JP Morgan, Wells Fargo, Citi and Delta Airlines

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took its cue from the fresh record levels on Wall St amid the backdrop of the trade optimism heading into this week’s Phase 1 deal signing and after the US removed its designation of China as a currency manipulator. ASX 200 (+0.9%) followed suit to its US peers and posted a fresh all-time high led by tech and defensives, as well as the broad sectoral gains aside from gold miners which lagged due to losses in the precious metal, while Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) tested the 24k milestone on return from an extended weekend and with early advances spurred by a predominantly favourable currency. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) also initially benefitted from the trade developments in which the US backtracked just 5 months after it had labelled China a currency manipulator and with the initial details of the Phase 1 deal said to confirm China’s pledge to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period, while the latest Chinese trade data added to the encouragement as Trade Balance, Exports and Imports mostly surpassed estimates for December although Chinese markets eventually gave back their gains and the data had also showed trade with the US contracted by 10.7% Y/Y throughout 2019. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower and slipped below the 152.00 with demand dampened by the gains across stocks and with a relatively tepid BoJ Rinban announcement for just JPY 130bln of JGBs doing little to underpin prices.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.8954 vs. Exp. 6.8957 (Prev. 6.9263)

 

US Treasury removed China from the currency manipulator list in its semi-annual report and said China made enforceable commitments to refrain from competitive devaluation in the Phase 1 deal but also noted that China needs to take necessary steps to avoid a persistently weak currency. Furthermore, the report added that no major US trading partner met the criteria to be designated a currency manipulator and that it is continuing to monitor China, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam and Switzerland currency practices, while Taiwan and Thailand are nearing the threshold to be added into the monitoring list. (Newswires)

   

US-China Phase 1 deal will include pledge by China to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period including USD 50bln in energy, USD 40bln in agriculture, USD 35bln-40bln in services and USD 75bln in manufactured goods. (Politico)

 

USTR Lighthizer said they have about finished translation of the Phase 1 deal which includes commitment regarding currency manipulation, while White House Trade Adviser Navarro commented that the Phase 1 deal will allow the US to swiftly reimpose tariffs if it unilaterally determines that China has broken any of its commitments. In related news, Chinese officials will meet with American companies to send the message that China is open for business, according to FBN's Lawrence citing sources. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Nov) 330B vs. Exp. 315.0B (Prev. 274.2B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (CNY)(Nov) Y/Y 9.0% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 1.3%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(Nov) Y/Y 17.7% vs. Exp. 8.8% (Prev. 2.5%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 46.79B vs. Exp. 48.0B (Prev. 37.93B) Chinese Exports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 7.6% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. -1.3%) Chinese Imports (USD)(Dec) Y/Y 16.3% vs. Exp. 9.6% (Prev. 0.5%)

 

China Customs noted that 2019 trade with US fell 10.7% Y/Y. There were also comments by Customs Vice Minister Zhou that the Phase 1 deal will boost Chinese imports from US but won't affect China's imports from other countries, while Zhou added that trade growth still faces complex external environment this year. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Economists warned that next BoE Governor Bailey and UK Chancellor Javid have to take early measures to ensure the BoE has tools to deploy for the next recession. (FT) Note, this was the findings of a survey conducted in December.

 

Senior US Officials told Ministers in the UK that utilising Huawei’s technology in the UK’s 5G network would place trans-Atlantic intelligence sharing at risk. (Guardian)

FX

DXY was steady below the 97.50 level amid indecisive trade across most its major counterparts with EUR/USD stuck around several DMA levels including the 200DMA at 1.1138 and with GBP/USD constrained below the 1.3000 handle as weak activity data added to the woes for the currency that had already been pressured from the increasingly dovish BoE rhetoric. Elsewhere, USD/JPY reclaimed 110.00 and JPY-crosses also broke out from the prior day’s ranges as the trade-related optimism and gains in stocks spurred safe-haven outflows, while CNH strengthened after a firmer PBoC reference rate setting and the US removal of its currency manipulator designation on China, which in turn supported AUD and NZD although the initial gains across the antipodeans eventually petered out heading into the Chinese trade data.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly subdued with WTI crude futures languishing near the prior day’s lows after having briefly attempted a breakdown of support at USD 58.00/bbl, with the recent declines attributed to an unwinding of the geopolitical risk premium concerning Iran, as well as the potential ceasefire in Libya which has so yet to materialize as LNA’s Haftar delegation left Moscow without signing the agreement and was said to have asked for more time until today to decide. Nonetheless, focus also shifts to the upcoming crude stockpile reports which S&P Global Platts noted are likely to show a 500k bbl build. Gold prices extended on losses with the mostly positive risk tone sapping safe-haven demand with the pressure also reflected on other precious metals, while copper plateaued but remained near 8-month highs.

GEOPOLITICS

 

Twitter reports stated that Libya’s GNA signed the ceasefire but LNA’s General Haftar left Moscow without signing the ceasefire according to sources, while reports also noted heavy gunfire in Salah al-Din and Ain Zara areas of Libya's capital Tripoli. (Twitter) 

US 

The TPLEX sold off modestly on Monday in a rather lacklustre session which saw growth in risk appetite, namely equities. The move lower happened primarily in the earlier European session, with EGBs leading the losses and the Treasury curve following suit, seeing Bunds break through some technical levels in absence of major news flow or tier 1 data. The overall sentiment on the Phase 1 deal is leaning towards the positive side in light on recent media reports, with participants anticipating some hard purchases figures in the deal to be released upon signing on Wednesday. This cautious optimism saw the Treasury curve steepen slightly, with the 2-year yield rising 1bps and the 30-year yield up by just shy of 2bps. Attention now draws towards US CPI and the initiation of earnings season on Tuesday for investors to attain a better gauge of economic sentiment. US T-note futures (H0) settled 5 ticks lower at 128-29+.

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Neutral) said the US economy is generally doing fine and the Fed should sit back and let the economy do as it is doing until something changes, while he does not see a recession in the near future. (Newswires)

US President Trump’s administration plans to reallocate USD 7.2bln of defence funds for the border wall. (Newswires)

US Senator Cornyn commented that the Senate could conduct a vote on USMCA this week. (Newswires)

The Trump Administration has taken steps to spare investors from Australia, Canada and the UK from some of its restrictions on foreign investments, due to take effect on February 13th. (FT) Yesterday, the Trump Administrations issues a set of rules that will look to intensify scrutiny of foreign investments in US companies.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac stocks are lifted after US drops China currency manipulator label, while Chinese trade data also tops estimates
content:
Asian equity markets are higher across the board as the region takes its cue from the fresh record levels on Wall St amid the backdrop of the trade optimism heading into this week’s Phase 1 deal signing and after the US removed its designation of China as a currency manipulator. ASX 200 (+0.7%) follows suit to its US peers and posted a fresh all-time high with tech and defensives leading the broad gains across its sectors aside from gold miners which lag due to further weakness in the precious metal, while Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) reclaimed the 24k milestone on return from the extended weekend with early gains spurred by a predominantly favourable currency. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) also benefitted from the trade developments in which the US backtracked just 5 months after it had labelled China a currency manipulator and with the initial details of the Phase 1 deal said to confirm China’s pledge to buy USD 200bln of US goods over a 2-year period, while the latest Chinese trade data added to the encouragement as Trade Balance, Exports and Imports all surpassed estimates for December although showed trade with the US contracted by 10.7% Y/Y during the whole of 2019.

In FX markets, the DXY is steady below the 97.50 level amid indecisive trade across most its major counterparts with EUR/USD little changed around several DMA levels including the 200DMA at 1.1138 and with GBP/USD constrained below the 1.3000 handle as weak data added to the woes for the currency that had already been pressured from the increasingly dovish BoE rhetoric. Elsewhere, USD/JPY reclaimed 110.00 and JPY-crosses also broke out from the prior day’s ranges as the trade-related optimism and gains in stocks spurred safe-haven outflows, while CNH strengthened after a firmer PBoC reference rate setting and the US removal of its currency manipulator designation on China, which in turn supported AUD and NZD although the initial gains across the antipodeans eventually petered out heading into the Chinese trade data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower and have slipped below the 152.00 with demand dampened by the gains across stocks and with a relatively tepid BoJ Rinban announcement for just JPY 130bln of JGBs doing little to underpin prices.
